ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book What a Cold Needs. We learned about how to take care of yourself when you have a cold.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of children doing different things. We will sort the pictures into two groups:

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Good for a Cold is for things that are good to do when you have a cold. These things will help you get better faster.
Bad for a Cold is for things that will not help you get better when you have a cold. These things won’t help you feel better.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Hand Signals Ask children to give a thumbs up if the picture shows something that is good for a cold, and thumbs down if it’s not.
Ask Show a picture card and ask the question on the back. Offer extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Sort Give the picture card to a child to line up in the “Good for a Cold” or “Bad for a Cold” column.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-card_run-in_hed: Talk About What is Good for a Cold
ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: All of the pictures in this group show things that are good to do when you have a cold. Why are these good things to do when you have a cold?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-card_run-in_hed: Talk About What is Bad for a Cold
ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: All of the pictures in this group show things that are bad to do when you have a cold. Why shouldn’t you do these things when you have a cold?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: For younger or developmentally-delayed children, read aloud the Ask and Support sections of each card. Say: It is not good to run around with other children if you have a cold because you could pass your cold onto someone else.

Show children two picture cards at a time, one from each group. Ask, What is different about these two activities? Why is one something good to do when you have a cold and the other is not? Repeat with other pairs of cards.

Provide children with any missing vocabulary they need to talk about what the children in the pictures are doing. For example, point to the children running and say, The children are running. Have children repeat after you. Provide them with sentence frames to help them formulate a response to the question.

Invite children to act out each of the activities that it is good to do when they have a cold (take a nap, read a book, put on warm socks). Challenge children to think of other activities that they can do when they have a cold and to act them out, too.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book What a Cold Needs. We learned about how people can help take care of you, along with things you can do for yourself.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of different objects. We will act out what you can do with that object to help you take care of yourself when you have a cold.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show a picture card and ask the question on the back. Offer extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Act It Out Act out what is shown on the picture card to show how to use it to take care of a cold.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Invite children to think of other things they can do to help themselves when they have a cold. See if other children can guess what those activities are.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: If children aren’t sure how to use the object in the picture to help themselves, have them work in pairs to act it out for each other. Talking things out with a partner might help children understand how they can help themselves feel better using the object in the picture.

Ask children which things they find to be the most helpful when they have a cold. Encourage peer-to-peer conversations with each child taking two turns in the conversation. Remind children that while one person is talking, the other is listening.

Use repetition to enhance children’s understanding of the vocabulary they need in order to talk about the objects in the pictures. For example, point to the blanket and say, This is a blanket. A blanket is used to keep people warm. It feels good to get under a blanket when you are cold. Have children repeat the name of the object, for example, blanket, each time you say it.

Challenge children to think of other objects that are helpful when they have a cold and to pretend they are using those objects too. They can make chicken soup, or pretend to read a book, or take a nap.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We will need blue modeling dough and red modeling dough for this activity.
Today we read the book What a Cold Needs. We learned that sometimes we can get others sick.

In this activity, we will explore different ways that germs can spread, and how to prevent that from happening. You will get small balls of dough. Some of you will get red dough and others will get blue dough.

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: If you have red dough, that means you have a cold!
If you have blue dough, that means you are healthy.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Do the Activity Give each child a small ball of dough. Half of the children should have red and half should have blue dough.
Tell a child with red dough: You just sneezed on (name a child with blue dough) and didn’t cover your mouth! Give a little of your red dough to (him/her).
Tell another: You washed your hands. Keep your dough to yourself!
Tell another child with red dough: You didn’t wash your hands and then you passed the snacks around. Give a little of your red dough to each person you gave a snack to.
Repeat Continue the activity and see how the red dough gets mixed in with the blue until everyone has germs.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: What other actions help stop germs from spreading? What else spreads germs?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Go over ways that germs spread: sneezing, coughing, touching. Review ways that prevent germs from spreading: covering your mouth, washing your hands, using tissues.
Ask a child to act out the best ways to cough and sneeze if you are sick, so that you don’t spread germs.
Provide children with any missing vocabulary they need to talk about germs. For example, define sneeze, cough, and touch by showing each of those actions.
Invite children to act out being germs and how they spread through the air, land on surfaces, and get passed around.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the Big Chart Keep Your Hands Clean. You learned about how to take care of yourself when you have a cold, and about hand washing.
In this activity, I will ask you to do two things and you will see if you can do them both:

section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: The things I will ask you to do are about washing your hands. We talked about this earlier when we looked at the Big Chart.
section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Remind children that they need to use their listening and remembering skills to do this activity.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: FIRST, I want you to hold out your hands and then pretend to get them wet. (Pause to let children do these two things.)
NEXT, I want you to pretend to scrub your hands with soap and then rinse them. (Pause again.)
LAST, I want you to pretend to dry your hands with a towel and then walk away from the sink.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Extend Ask children why it is important to wash their hands. Ask why it is important to wash their hands for a certain length of time.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-card_run-in_hed: Ask Why We Wash Our Hands
ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Why do you think you should wash your hands when you have a cold? Should you wash your hands when you do not have a cold? Why or why not?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About Why We Wash Our Hands Help children understand that they should wash their hands when they’re sick and when they’re not so that they don’t spread germs or catch them.
Act out the directions as you give them to children. Be careful not to speak too fast and to simplify each step as needed.
Add an extra step to the directions. Say, for example, Hold out your hands, pretend to turn the water on, and then pretend to get your hands wet.
When giving directions to children, act out the steps you describe and have children repeat and act out each one after you.

Helping children focus their attention is a critical learning milestone for preschoolers. You can help children focus their attention through a variety of strategies, including using simple directions and previewing each activity before you begin. Model what to do, and check to make sure that all children know what to do.
